# Chapter 294

*What method...? How can we escape this crisis?*

Grid had survived countless raids. He'd climbed levels through boss fights rather than grinding mobs. If there was one thing he excelled at, it was performing under pressure. And unlike most raid bosses, the enemies he'd faced weren't mindless monsters howling "Kuwoooh!" before charging.

Satisfy's named bosses shaped the game's world. Each possessed distinct personalities, histories, and motivations. That singularity had taught Grid an unconventional approach. Where others memorized attack patterns and cooldown timers, he studied psychology. Understanding a boss's nature, their drives and obsessions, turned impossible fights into winnable ones.

The Pascal raid hadn't been a test of strength. It had been theater. Manipulation. Grid had orchestrated the entire scenario to ensure victory.

*I could've been a raid consultant,* Grid thought idly. *Selling strategies to guilds. Making actual money from this talent.*

The idea died as quickly as it formed. He lacked the business acumen to monetize anything.

*Elfin Stone is the key.*

Grid's mind worked through the problem. The vampire earl could annihilate their entire party whenever he wished. Yet over four days, he'd killed only one person per night. Why the restraint?

*Entertainment.*

Elfin Stone savored their terror. Each calculated murder maximized fear, watching them fracture under the psychological pressure.

*He wants us scared and broken.*

If the vampire simply wanted them dead, he'd have slaughtered everyone immediately.

*That would end the game too quickly.*

The earl didn't want corpses. He wanted toys.

*I can use this.*

Grid's expression darkened as the plan solidified.

"Rapid Pressure."

Peeeeeong!

While Grid strategized, the Overgeared members fought desperately. Huroi maintained aggro through constant provocation, allowing Vantner to focus on defense while the damage dealers attacked from multiple angles.

They moved like a precision instrument. Each member's unique abilities created synergies that amplified their total output beyond simple addition. These were top-twenty rankers, the best players in the world, demonstrating exactly why they held those positions.

Faker's performance bordered on supernatural. His speed made even Elfin Stone's reactions seem sluggish. The assassin's dagger opened crimson lines across pale flesh before the vampire could shift into smoke form.

But Blood Field negated everything. Elfin Stone recovered over 1,000 health per second by draining the Overgeared members. His total health pool seemed bottomless. Grid estimated eight million. Impossible to burn down with just eight players.

"Lightning Kill!"

Kwajijijik!

Regas' fist punched clean through Elfin Stone's chest. The vampire's torso dissolved into smoke at the point of impact, reforming instantly.

"Got you!"

Without retracting his arm, Regas twisted his entire body. His heel arced toward Elfin Stone's skull. An unorthodox, flowing strike.

"Kkuk...!"

Elfin Stone grunted. He'd anticipated a follow-up punch, not the spinning kick. Before he could recover, Pon closed the distance.

"Rain Spear!"

Pepeng! Pepepeng!

The spearman leapt, his weapon blurring into a downpour of thrusts. An unavoidable skill. Elfin Stone could transform his entire body to smoke to evade, but the technique created massive recovery lag. He'd be helpless afterward.

"Blood Shield!"

Jjejeong! Jjeejeeeong!

Elfin Stone converted his own health into scarlet barriers. Dozens of shields materialized, intercepting Pon's assault mid-air.

Puk! Puk puk!

Faker materialized behind the vampire. His dagger found the neck again and again, exploiting Iyarugt's combo system to stack damage.

Elfin Stone's head snapped around. "I'll deal with you first!"

"...!"

Faker tensed. The vampire's attention had shifted from Huroi.

Peeng!

Iyarugt pulsed crimson. 

> **[Blood Cry]**

Chiing!

The Overgeared members staggered, ears ringing, balance shattered. Elfin Stone seized the opening.

"Blood Thorns!"

Puuok! Puuok!

Crimson spikes erupted from Blood Field, impaling Faker's thighs. The attack dealt minimal damage, but the thorns carried a vicious debuff. They corrupted the bloodstream, drastically reducing movement speed. Faker's greatest asset, his mobility, evaporated.

Elfin Stone smiled. Iyarugt rose, aimed at the assassin's neck. Flaming arrows intercepted the blade before it could descend.

Jishuka provided cover from range.

"Entertaining," Elfin Stone murmured. "You humans show promise."

The longer this continued, the more the advantage tilted toward the vampire.

Kwajak!

Elfin Stone snapped an arrow with casual force. His health remained at eight-tenths. The Overgeared members had lost between one-third and half their health pools. Blood Field was grinding them down.

Zednos cast Blessing of the Wind on Faker, restoring his movement speed. "At this rate, we're wiped in two minutes."

Vantner grunted agreement.

Elfin Stone's individual stats, attack power, magic power, defense, speed, weren't exceptional for a boss of his level. What made him overwhelming was utility. Area-of-effect drains. Wide-range offensive and defensive skills. Vampire racial abilities. Single-target defensive techniques. An endless toolkit.

They'd need the entire Overgeared Guild to have a chance. Could even a level 300 Grid defeat this monster alone?

Doubt crept into their minds.

Then Grid's whisper arrived.

> **{Sacrifice Huroi. Elfin Stone's rampage is because of him. The vampire will stop after Huroi dies.}**

What?

"...?"

Everyone except Huroi froze. Regas rolled away from Iyarugt's sweeping arc, his voice tight with disbelief.

> **{Selling out our companion? Tell me I heard that wrong.}**

Grid shook his head.

> **{You heard correctly.}**

Pon's shout cracked with anger.

> **{Don't make us lose faith in you!}**

Jishuka's response was ice.

> **{A man who betrays his allies doesn't deserve to lead anyone.}**

Peak Sword, Zednos, and Faker remained silent, but their discomfort radiated through the mental link. The criticism was warranted, natural even.

Grid met their judgment without flinching. When he spoke, his voice carried absolute conviction.

"This is to protect the others."

He wasn't sacrificing Huroi arbitrarily.

*One death saves eight lives.*

Most people couldn't make that calculation, especially when the variable was someone they valued. Sentiment clouded logic. But Grid operated on ruthless pragmatism. Emotional decisions? Not his style. Never had been.

"Cough!"

An attack hammered Faker. Grid surged forward and drew Failure.

Chaaeng!

Blue orichalcum clashed against blood-red stone.

> **[The durability of +9 Failure has decreased by 5.]**

The blood stone's hardness far exceeded blue orichalcum. Perhaps even surpassed adamantium.

*Iyarugt's creator outclasses my current skill level.*

Grid clicked his tongue and opened a private whisper to Huroi.

> **—Do you understand what I'm asking? You need to die for everyone else.**

Huroi's response came instantly.

> **—I understand, My Lord.**

No hesitation. No protest. Grid's chest constricted.

> **—Why don't you ever push back? It makes this worse, you being so goddamn obedient.**

> **—I exist to follow your commands. When those orders are logical, like now, I'm even more willing.**

The death penalties were brutal. Experience loss. Item durability damage. Potential drops. For someone like Huroi, whose combat weakness made leveling agonizingly slow, the cost multiplied.

Yet he never balked.

> **—I'll get revenge on Elfin Stone. And I'll compensate you enough to offset today's loss. You have my word.**

> **—Compensation is unnecessary. Sacrificing myself for you and those you value is my purpose. I want nothing in return. Besides, this situation is my fault—**

> **—You're not responsible. And don't forget, you're one of those precious people too.**

> **—...**

Grid steeled himself. He turned to Elfin Stone, who watched him with cold amusement over their crossed blades.

"I'll hand over the companion who insulted your parents." Grid's voice carried no emotion. "Kill him. Satisfy your anger."

Elfin Stone's eyes widened fractionally.

"Selling out your ally to preserve your own life?" A laugh, sharp and cruel. "Humans truly are filthy, pathetic creatures."

"So you refuse?"

A smile split Elfin Stone's pale face.

"On the contrary. I accept."

*Exactly as predicted.*

Elfin Stone wanted to prolong the hunt. Make the game last.

Grid stepped back from the vampire. "Go die."

Huroi moved immediately. He sprinted toward Elfin Stone. The other members shouted.

"No!"

"What are you doing, you insane—"

Their protests meant nothing. Grid had decided. Huroi obeyed Grid.

"I'll make this exquisite."

Puok!

Huroi didn't resist as Elfin Stone toyed with him. Blood Thorns pierced his ankles, pinning him in place. Iyarugt slashed his wrists, severing tendons. Then the vampire began carving, treating Huroi's body like a butcher block. Methodical cuts. Precise mutilation.

Finally, the blade cleaved into his skull.

"..."

The pain simulation was dulled compared to reality, but the psychological trauma remained visceral. Huroi endured in absolute silence. His mind had been forged during hundreds of hours trapped in darkness. This was nothing.

"I can't watch this!"

The Overgeared members trembled with righteous fury. Grid's voice cut through their building rage.

"Control yourselves and retreat. Now. Anyone who disobeys gets expelled from the guild."

"..."

Grid had never possessed traditional charisma. His high Dignity stat meant nothing when he constantly undermined himself chasing gold and glory. He seemed frivolous. Weak.

But now, something had shifted. Guilt and sorrow warred behind his eyes. He forced the emotions down, burying them beneath iron composure. 

The Overgeared members saw it. The weight he carried. The cost of command.

They retreated.

On that day, Huroi died.
